subject: Problem with Request.method() and filtering classes with suite() method
msgSnippet: Hi all, I wondered if I m doing something wrong (most likely :) ) or whether there is some design bug in the current 4.3.1 code: I have a bunch of testcases
messageBody:
Hi all,

I wondered if I'm doing something wrong (most likely :) ) or whether
there is some design bug in the current 4.3.1 code:

I have a bunch of testcases (JUnit4 with annotations) flying around but
I just want to run only a subset of those tests and decide (at runtime)
which ones I want to run (e.g. reading a config file etc and
instantiating the according Requests and passing them to eg the
JUnitCore)
More precisely, I wanted to run just one method at a time.

From what I understand I need to create a Request that I can pass into
the JUnitCore in order to have it run.

So I discovered that there is the option to create a Request that should
be filtered already by using Request.method() which says that it "will
run a single test. This is done by filtering out all other tests."

Now when I do that and pass that to the JUnitCore it still runs all
tests/methods in that class :( .. am I missing something?
(I suspect its related to the problem further down.. which in essence
would be that I cannot filter testcases that have a suite() method)

Furthermore I tried to implement my own Filter which would just filter
out all unwanted methods using a Description.
Now there it seems that JUnit currently doesnt allow me to filter test
classes that contain the pre-v4 suite() methods
(unless I explicitly create the Request using
Request.classWithoutSuiteMethod())

If I create the Request as ususal (Request.aClass()) the Runner that
gets created internally is a AllTests Runner which doesnt implement
Filterable. As a result any filter.apply(Runner runner) calls have no
effect and the test is executed according to the suite() method.
So effectively I cannot filter test classes that have a suite() method.

Is that a desired behavior?
Should this be documented?


This is some sample code to illustrate what I need to do to have a
Filter actually be applied to my Test class (i.e. with that code I get
just the testMethodName method invoked on the test class clazz ).

// make a description with the methodname string
final Description d2 = Description.createTestDescription(clazz,
testMethodName);

// anonymous inner class filtering out all tests where the description
// differs from this methodnames description
f = new Filter(){
/** run only the test where the description matches */
public boolean shouldRun(Description d) {
return d2.equals(d);
}
public String describe() {
return "allows only methodname = "+ testMethodName;
}
};

// weird hack: because most of our test cases have a suite method
// junit creates a AllTests runner which does not implement Filterable
// and hence the filter has no effect (and all methods are invoked)
// so as a fix we create a request for a class without suite() method
request = Request.classWithoutSuiteMethod(clazz);




Thanks,

Sebastian
